summary: A graphical look at how different investments, from REIT shares to crude oil, fared last week.

summary: Pepper...and Salt

summary: What's News: Business & Finance: Top Stories for June 17, 2011

headline: A Distinct Distaste  For a Certain City
summary: Texas Gov. Rick Perry represents an increasingly common dissatisfaction with what goes on in Washington.

headline: Saving Social Security
summary: Try your hand at adjusting taxes and benefits to make Social Security solvent.

headline: Bears Feast on BlackBerry
summary: Options bears cleaned up on profitable trades made just days ahead of Research In Motion's stock slide, while others built pessimistic bets farther down the BlackBerry supply chain in Jabil Circuit.

headline: India's Inverted Oil Market
summary: When investors around the world speculate on rising crude-oil prices, Indian oil companies have a different dilemma: whether New Delhi will let them profit from the surge or not.

headline: Obama, Boehner Golf in Debt Talks' Shadow
summary: The golf date between President Barack Obama and Republican House Speaker John Boehner comes amid bipartisan talks on deficit reduction, but few expect a breakthrough on the links.

headline: Indicators Gain, but Consumers Gloomy
summary: The U.S. index of leading economic indicators rebounded in May, but consumer sentiment levels fell as of the middle of June, according to two data reports.

headline: Goldman Sachs Warns About Bullish Yuan Bet
summary: Goldman Sachs is telling hedge funds to close out a bet that China's currency will strengthen against the U.S. dollar, the latest sign of increased jitters about the strength of China's economy.

headline: The Making of an Iconic Ball
summary: Here's a look inside the Shelton Conn., factory responsible for every single Wiffle Ball that has sailed across backyards since the factory opened in 1959.

headline: Photos of the Day: June 17
summary: In today's pictures, an ear cleaner awaits clients in Pakistan, a baseball player mourns a loss in Wisconsin, a window cleaner works in Bulgaria, and more.

headline: California Puts Brake on Parks
summary: California's state parks are in a downward spiral of budget cuts that has left many partially closed and in decrepit condition heading into the busy summer season.

headline: Dow Industrials Snap Six-Week Losing Streak
summary: The Dow industrials snapped a six-week losing streak, with investors pushing up shares as hopes intensified for a resolution to the Greek debt crisis.

headline: Japan Plant Starts Treating Radioactive Water
summary: A system for decontaminating highly radioactive water incorporating U.S. and French technology began full operations at Japan's Fukushima Daiichi nuclear complex.

headline: PNC Financial Wins Bid
summary: PNC Financial Services won the bid for Royal Bank of Canada's U.S. retail banking business.

headline: Ohio Law Curbing Unions Faces Ballot Initiative
summary: A labor-backed group in Ohio said it had more than three times the number of signatures needed to get a recently passed state law that curbs union rights onto the November ballot, where unions hope to defeat it.

headline: Regulators Close Georgia, Florida Banks
summary: The FDIC said two banks failed, McIntosh State Bank in Georgia and First Commercial Bank of Tampa Bay in Florida, to bring the tally of closures so far this year to 47.

headline: U.S. Formally Drops Charges Against bin Laden
summary: Federal prosecutors formally dropped criminal charges against Osama bin Laden following his death last month in a raid by U.S. forces.

headline: Carlyle Names IPO Bankers
summary: Carlyle Grouphas chosen J.P. Morgan Chase & Co., Citigroup Inc. and Credit Suisse Group AG as the lead underwriters for its forthcoming initial public offering, according to a person familiar with the matter.

headline: 'Shale-Gas Age' Is Already Upon Us
summary: World-wide rising demand for natural gas, availability of immense shale resources, the propagating fall-out from the recent nuclear disaster in Japan and myriad other geo-political circumstances all point out that a "shale-gas age" is not only imminent, but already upon us.

headline: Talks Begin on Ethanol Compromise
summary: After a broad display of support for repealing ethanol subsidies in the U.S. Senate, lawmakers are in talks about a compromise that could preserve some form of an ethanol tax credit while providing a boost to companies that produce the fuel from sources other than corn.

headline: Moody's Puts Italy's Rating on Watch
summary: Moody's placed Italy on notice, warning that its sovereign rating may be imperiled by a weak economy and rising interest rates.

headline: Cadila to Buy Assets of U.S.-Based Nesher Pharmaceuticals
summary: Cadila Healthcare, a part of the Zydus Group, said its U.S. unit has agreed to acquire the assets of U.S.-based pharmaceutical company Nesher Pharmaceuticals for an undisclosed amount.

headline: New York Photos of the Week: June 13-17
summary: The district attorney touts a big breakthrough, a downpour hits Midtown, and more from across Greater New York.

headline: Corporate Bond Supply Slows
summary: Corporate bond issuance fell to its slowest pace of the year this week as investors grew increasingly wary of risk.

headline: Supply Worries Spur Corn Prices
summary: The price of a corn bushel is outpacing futures prices in some parts of the U.S., a rare phenomenon that underscores worries about a lack of the grain used to feed livestock and poultry.

headline: Pretty in Pink and Plastic
summary: Tarina Tarantino is the haute designer of playful jewelry for grown women, says the Journal's Christina Binkley.

headline: DOJ to Review Google Deal
summary: The Justice Department will conduct the antitrust review of Google's approximately $400 million purchase of Internet advertising company Admeld.

headline: Oil Hits Four-Month Low
summary: Crude-oil futures ended down 2%, hitting a four-month low, on concern that the Greek debt crisis and sluggish U.S. economic growth would damp fuel consumption.

headline: Little Change to Biofuel's Prospect
summary: The Senate vote to end ethanol tax breaks is a political blow to the Midwest-centered industry. By itself, though, it doesn't much change ethanol's immediate prospects.

headline: Goldman: Get Out of Bullish Yuan Bet
summary: Goldman Sachs Group is telling hedge funds to close out a bet that China's currency will strengthen against the U.S. dollar, in the latest sign of increased jitters over China's economy.

headline: Jurors Deliberate in Expert-Network Trial
summary: Jurors began their deliberations in the first insider-trading trial stemming from a wide-ranging government probe of expert-network firms.

headline: IMF Cuts Global Growth Forecast
summary: The International Monetary Fund slightly lowered its estimate for global growth for this year to 4.3%, and said Europe's debt crisis and unexpectedly weak growth in the U.S. pose greater dangers to the global recovery than originally forecast.

headline: Man in Custody After Pentagon Scare
summary: A Marine Corps reservist remained in custody after he was detained in the middle of the night near the Pentagon with a backpack containing suspicious items, officials said.

headline: FAA Proposes Fine Against United
summary: The FAA said it proposed a $584,375 civil penalty against United Airlines for allegedly violating federal regulations concerning random drug and alcohol testing of employees.

headline: Photos of the Day
summary: In Friday's pictures, an ear cleaner awaits clients in Pakistan, a baseball player mourns a loss in Wisconsin, a window cleaner works in Bulgaria, and more.

headline: Gold Inches Higher
summary: Gold closed slightly higher as traders eyed Europe's efforts to stem the Greek sovereign-debt crisis.

headline: N.Y. Pool Week: Which Home Makes a Splash?
summary: As temperatures rise, homes with pools become a very cool option. Where would you take the plunge? Cast your vote below.

headline: RIM Shares Dive
summary: After slashing its profit forecast for the year and saying it would be shedding jobs, RIM saw its share price drop sharply again Friday.

headline: Chinese Firm Denies Short-Seller Allegations
summary: Harbin Electric, a Chinese electric-motor company whose shares are traded on Nasdaq, denied report by short-seller Citron Research that questioned the chief executive's proposal to take the firm private, saying the allegations contained "factual errors" and "out-of-context information."

headline: Graham Accepts Reynolds Offer
summary: Graham Packaging accepted Reynolds Group's sweetened $1.69 billion acquisition offer and will pay a termination fee to Silgan Holdings.

headline: Greece Axes Finance Minister in Reshuffle
summary: Greece's embattled Socialist government announced a sweeping cabinet reshuffle, replacing the country's finance minister in an effort to shore up support for unpopular economic reforms.

headline: FDA Panel Backs Regeneron Eye Drug
summary: An FDA panel backed a Regeneron eye drug used for the treatment of a condition that can lead to blindness.

headline: Fujitsu Forecasts Japan IT Spending Rebound
summary: Fujitsu forecast a sharp decline in earnings for its fiscal first half, but a modest growth in net profit for the full year, as Japanese corporate clients spend more on information-technology services.

headline: TNK-BP Nears Deal For Stake in Brazil Deposit
summary: BP's Russian joint venture TNK-BP hopes to close a deal to buy a 45% stake in an oil and gas deposit in Brazil's Solimoes region from Petra Energia SA within one month, the company's Deputy Chief Executive Maxim Barsky said.

headline: Coal Firms Lose Fight Over Clean-Up Fees
summary: Coal companies appear to have lost a lengthy legal battle to try to recover millions of dollars paid to the federal government to clean up abandoned mines.

headline: Clock Ticks For Swiss Watchmaking
summary: While Swatch's decision to reduce its supply of watch parts makes commercial sense, it could damage Swiss industry dominance.

headline: FDIC Nears WaMu Settlement
summary: The FDIC is close to settling a lawsuit that accused former Washington Mutual executives of taking gambles that sparked the thrift's 2008 collapse.

headline: G-20 Ministers to Seek Ways to Avoid Food Crisis
summary: Agriculture ministers of the Group of 20 countries are hoping to unveil ambitious projects next week to stabilize and sustain world food supplies, France's agricultural minister said.

headline: Ryanair and Comac Forge Cooperating Agreement
summary: A pact between Ryanair and China's state-owned Comac will focus on development of Comac's C919 jet, according to a person familiar with the talks.

summary: Before you start packing up your desk, our columnist offers some advice.

summary: Bill Streever discovers the beauty and mystery of an Alaskan glacier.

summary: European stock markets recovered from early losses to close higher after France and Germany made a united call for swift action on a new Greek aid package.

summary: A June 1 letter from European Commissioners Michel Barnier and Olli Rehn to U.K. Chancellor of the Exchequer George Osborne. The letter's authenticity has been confirmed.

summary: Fonterra, a giant New Zealand dairy firm, sold the first offshore yuan-denominated bond from that country.

headline: Tony Hayward's Return
summary: Eight months after the Deepwater Horizon disaster chased Tony Hayward from the chief executive's post at BP, Vallares, a new investment vehicle he co-founded, raised a third more than expected via a London stock-market listing.

headline: Resort Wear from the Urban Jungle to the Wild West
summary: Philip Lim and Tory Burch create looks for the super chic and the super laid-back.

headline: Philip Lim and Tory Burch
summary: Philip Lim's resort collection was "often smart, at times whimsical," says the Journal's Ray Smith. Tory Burch, he writes, was "alluring...and trippy."

headline: Carrefour Tones Down Earnings Expectations
summary: French retailer Carrefour forecasts operating income in France in the first half of the year to fall 35% compared with the same period a year earlier, a company spokesman said.

headline: Boston Scientific Recalls Stent
summary: Boston Scientific has recalled a new stent for leg arteries, available outside the U.S. thus far, because of deployment issues that could lead to emergency surgery, the FDA said.

headline: Spain's Bad Loans Hit 16-Year High
summary: Spain's central bank said bad debt at the country's commercial banks soared in April to the worst level in 16 years.

headline: Bipartisan House Letter on Social Security Qualification
summary: Top Republicans and Democrats on the House subcommittee that oversees Social Security called for an investigation into the way administrative-law judges determine whether someone qualifies for disability benefits. Read the letter.

headline: Emerging Europe: The Week in Photos
summary: See photos from across Central and Eastern Europe, including protests in the Czech Republic, Hungary and Poland.

headline: Rains Hit India Rice Heartland
summary: Heavy monsoon rains have hit India's rice-growing eastern region after a delay, senior weather officials said, brightening prospects of a good crop, with the seasonal rains covering other key farm regions on time.

headline: Pantaloon Retail May Sell Stake if Rules Ease
summary: Pantaloon Retail India is open to selling stakes in its retail and insurance businesses when the government eases foreign direct investment rules.

headline: Agencies See Decade of High Food Prices
summary: Food prices will be up to 30% higher on average over the next decade as slowing grains production fails to keep pace with rising demand, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said.

headline: No Quick Fixes for Areva
summary: The stakes are high for Luc Oursel, who will become CEO of Areva next month, amid an uncertain outlook for the engineering group that is one of France's two state-controlled nuclear champions.

headline: UPS Is Restricted in Britain
summary: The U.K. said it has barred United Parcel Service from screening air cargo at some British transport facilities due to concerns about its security procedures.

headline: Nasdaq Confirms LCH.Clearnet Bid
summary: Nasdaq OMX Chief Executive Bob Greifeld confirmed the exchange group is bidding for a minority stake in LCH.Clearnet, following nearly three weeks of speculation regarding a possible takeover of the independent Anglo-French clearing house.

headline: BJ's Receives Buyout Offer
summary: BJ's Wholesale Club has received a takeover offer from a group including the private-equity firms Green Equity Investors, Leonard Green & Partners and CVC Capital Partners.

headline: Korea May Be Best Off Halting Woori Sale
summary: Seoul wants to sell its 57% stake in Woori, but buyers are sparse. A pullout would be a bitter pill to swallow for the current administration, but the best thing for it to do may be to lay the groundwork for a future sale

headline: U.K. Pension Push Angers Unions
summary: U.K. treasury minister Danny Alexander inflamed union passions with his plans to overhaul public-sector pensions, which will see the retirement age raised and pension contributions increased.

headline: Santander Sees No Profit Growth in 2011
summary: Banking giant Banco Santander expects net profit this year to be in line with the $11.62 billion it reported in 2010, Chairman Emilio Botin said.

headline: Celesio Shares Plunge
summary: Shares in German pharmaceutical retailer Celesio plummeted after the company issued a profit warning and said it had underestimated the intensity of competition in Germany's pharmaceutical wholesale business.

headline: Tech Stocks Drag India Shares
summary: Indian shares slipped 0.6%, falling for the third consecutive session Friday, mirroring weak Asian markets, with losses led by heavyweight Reliance Industries and technology stocks.

headline: India, China to Resume Military Ties
summary: India and China will resume military ties a year after a cold freeze in relations, with a defense delegation set to travel to Beijing on Sunday, according to an official in the Indian government.

headline: Maruti Workers Call Off Strike
summary: Workers at a Maruti Suzuki car factory late Thursday withdrew a strike which lasted for nearly two weeks and halted production and caused a revenue loss of 4.2 billion rupees ($94 million).

headline: Greenpeace Again Scales Oil Rig
summary: The head of Greenpeace has scaled an oil rig off Greenland, defying a court order aimed at stopping activists from disrupting a controversial Arctic drilling campaign.

headline: Europe Debt-Insurance Costs Pull Back
summary: The cost of insuring European sovereign debt against default came down from opening levels after soothing comments from euro-zone leaders.

headline: India Solar Mission on Track
summary: India's Jawaharlal Nehru National Solar Mission has a stated goal of developing 20,000 megawatts of solar energy in three phases by 2022.

headline: Lenovo CEO Yang Increases Stake
summary: Lenovo Group Chief Executive Yang Yuanqing bought about 8% of the company's  outstanding shares from its biggest shareholder, Legend Holdings.

headline: London Loses in ENRC Board Games
summary: London prides itself on being a magnet for emerging-market companies seeking access to equity markets. But recently that success has taken on a sour note.

headline: PCCW Seeks Support for Business Trust Listing
summary: PCCW Ltd. Chairman Richard Li moved to galvanize shareholder support for a plan to list the company's telecom assets as a business trust by highlighting that dividend payments from a trust could be much higher than from a regular share offering.

headline: What if Greeks Don't Want to Be Rescued?
summary: Reports suggest the EU, ECB and IMF  might have come up with a temporary deal among themselves over Greece, but what they want won't matter unless they get the Greek government to play as well. And that's by no means assured

headline: Asian Shares Mostly Down on Greek Woes
summary: Asian stock markets were mostly lower, as sentiment remained fragile due to continued concerns over Greek debt woes. Japan's Nikkei Stock Average was off 0.6%.

headline: Greek Drama Spooks Bond Market
summary: The cost of insuring Greek government bonds against default soared to another record as a growing crisis cast doubt on the country's ability to continue qualifying for international aid.

headline: Max India to Buy Warburg Pincus' Stake in Unit
summary: Max India's board has approved buying Warburg Pincus Group's 16.4% stake in Max Healthcare Institute for $31 million.

headline: Medvedev Pledges Economic Reforms
summary: Russian President Dmitry Medvedev promised Friday to implement more and bolder economic reforms and liberalization in the country.

headline: Toyota Cites Progress in Quake Recovery
summary: Toyota Motor's president said the company's domestic and overseas plants will return to full output in July, suggesting that the auto maker is nearing an end to the disruptions caused by the March 11 earthquake.

headline: Woodside Project Faces Delay, Cost Overruns
summary: Woodside Petroleum faces a six-month delay and $950 million budget overrun at its flagship Pluto gas-export project, sending the company's shares lower and putting the project under a cloud.

headline: Euro-Zone Posts Trade-Balance Deficit
summary: The euro zone's trade balance swung into deficit in April after exports fell more sharply than imports from March, the European Union's statistics agency reported.

headline: Enel CEO Sees Coal as Alternative to Nuclear
summary: Enel SpA's Chief Executive Fulvio Conti said the Italian utility will invest more in coal plants following a ban on nuclear energy and expects coal could account for 20% of Italy's total energy consumption in few years time, up from 14% now.

headline: ONGC Plans to Spend $39 Billion to Raise Output
summary: Oil & Natural Gas Corp. plans to spend as much as 1.75 trillion rupees ($39 billion) in the five years starting April 2012, as India's flagship explorer seeks to lift output to meet surging demand for energy in Asia's third-largest economy.

headline: India in Pictures
summary: A shepherd in Maharashtra, a statue of Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel, a toy seller at India Gate and more.

headline: Airline-Emissions Plan Draws Fire
summary: The U.S. is preparing to deliver its first formal objections to the European Union's impending emission-trading plan for airlines.

headline: Asia in Pictures
summary: Radical cleric convicted in Indonesia, garment workers fainting at Vietnamese factories, graduation ceremony forAfghan soldiers, and more.

headline: World Watch
summary: World Watch items for Friday June 17, 2011.

headline: Island Living
summary: A 40-minute ferry ride from the Central business district can transport Hong Kongers to what feels like a world away. This 1,700-square-foot home in Mui Wo, a car-restricted neighborhood on Lantau Island, has been rented to families of airline pilots to use as a holiday house.

headline: A Haven From The Bustle
summary: Villa Souane Chbar ("garden villa" in Khmer) sits along the Mekong River, 30 minutes by car outside of Phnom Penh, off a dirt road. In the morning, warm breezes and the soft put-put-put of fishing boat motors drift up from the river.

headline: Pilot-Fatigue Rules Fight Heats Up
summary: The fight over new European pilot-fatigue rules is heating up, with union leaders and Danish government officials on Thursday challenging the safety of proposed regulatory changes.

headline: An Author's Abode in Atlanta -- Photos
summary: The original owners of best-selling author Emily Giffin's home in Atlanta wanted it to look like older homes in the neighborhood. To make it blend in, they chose a slate roof, mature landscaping and antique doorknobs.

headline: Deadline to End Afghan Surge
summary: The military is asking Obama to hold off on ending the Afghanistan troop surge until the fall of 2012, in a proposal that would keep a large portion of the 33,000 extra forces in the country through the next two warm-weather fighting seasons.

headline: Unemployment Claims Fall but Job Market Stays Weak
summary: Claims filed by unemployed Americans fell last week but remained above 400,000. Separately, U.S. home construction rose modestly in May but are still sluggish.

headline: Toulouse-Lautrec and His Dancing Muse
summary: The Courtauld Gallery's "Toulouse-Lautrec and Jane Avril" exhibition takes the artist's "Jane Avril in the Entrance to the Moulin Rouge" from its collection and enhances our understanding of it, and of the artist and his world, by generous loans from other institutions.

headline: Beau's Braced for Open Charge
summary: Beau Hossler, the third-youngest golfer to qualify for a U.S. Open at 16, challenges the 'normal dudes' at the top of world golf.

headline: Jakarta's Wrong Turn
summary: Industrial policy always sounds better than it turns out in practice.

headline: Poet Stephen Dunn Returns
summary: The Queens-born poet chats about his new collection and avoiding bad endings.

headline: Gadhafi Offer to Hold Vote Rejected
summary: Col. Moammar Gadhafi's son said the strongman was willing to hold free elections and step aside if he loses, while Russia and China urged the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to "meticulously adhere" to United Nations' resolutions authorizing force in the war-torn country.

headline: How Long Can IMF Play the Contortionist?
summary: It was IMF concerns about Greece's funding shortfalls that brought the issue to a head in the first place. But in the end, it looks like the IMF will be the one to blink.

headline: Fleming Heats Up the Paris Stage
summary: The revival of Andrei Serban's 2003 production of Verdi's "Otello" at the Opéra Bastille gets off to a fairly pedestrian start, but things warm up considerably by the third act.

headline: Theater Out of Theology
summary: Director Jonathan Kent, designer Paul Brown and lighting designer Mark Henderson have used all the bells and whistles of the National Theatre's Olivier in a serious attempt to make theater out of the ditzy theology of "Emperor and Galilean."

headline: Greek Uncertainty Lifts Treasurys
summary: Concern about the Greek debt situation combined with a flurry of negative headlines to produce a safe-haven market with higher prices across the board, extending Treasurys' two-month-long bull run.

headline: IEA: High Oil Price a Risk
summary: There is a "clear need" for OPEC to increase supplies to meet surging oil demand later this year, the International Energy Agency said, further emphasizing the divide between producers and consumers over how much oil the world needs.

headline: An Author's Abode in Atlanta
summary: Author Emily Giffin's abode in Atlanta is on the market for $2.1 million. The desk where she wrote three of her five books is negotiable.

headline: Parties Prep for Special Election
summary: Party leaders plan to move swiftly to identify potential successors to Rep. Anthony Weiner as they prepare for a special election.

headline: Saving for a Down Payment Amid Rising Rents
summary: A renter who wants to buy is having trouble saving for a down payment because the landlord keeps raising the rent. How can he save?

headline: 'The British Dilemma'
summary: How to let banks fail without endangering depositors?

headline: Hitler's Golden Book
summary: The curious history of Tacitus's little treatise about some troublesome northern tribes. Ferdinand Mount reviews "A Most Dangerous Book."

headline: Athletes' Tweets, By the Numbers
summary: We found the five active athletes in each of the four major sports with the most followers and tracked 100 of their most recent tweets.

headline: Firms Adjust to Hacks
summary: With hacking breaches more commonplace, an industry of experts has emerged to help companies formulate breach-response plans—often before an incident occurs.

headline: London's New Luxury Hotel, Lufthansa's New Baggage Rules
summary: News briefs for the Europe-based business traveler.

headline: FAA Set to Give Investors Peek at M&A Air
summary: The FAA soon will provide some big news—to investors, not just fliers. Investors may be able to track where corporate jets are flying and perhaps glean information about mergers in the making.

headline: Young Stars of Swedish Cuisine
summary: By doing away with a set menu, and banishing any prejudice about where to find the best food, chefs Björn Frantzén and Daniel Lindenberg daily reinvent a dozen courses.

headline: Tower Up for Sale on Sixth Avenue
summary: With New York City commercial real-estate prices rising back to peak levels, 1211 Sixth Ave. is hitting the sales block, one of the largest Midtown Manhattan office towers to do so since the economy turned in 2008.

headline: In Italy, Summer Starts at the Beach
summary: Italy's summer vacation season opened with the close of school last week, and despite current economic ills, a recent survey shows that seven out of 10 Italians will travel again this summer, about the same number as in 2010.

headline: Prada, Samsonite Show Strain on Hong Kong IPOs
summary: Prada and Samsonite took hits in the Hong Kong market, raising doubts over the continued strength of initial public offerings in a city that has taken the global crown for new listings for the past two years.

headline: Reflections of a Southern Man
summary: Neil Young talks about his new album, "A Treasure."

headline: Anouska Hempel's Yin and Yang
summary: Interior designer Anouska Hempel talks about the relaunch of London's iconic hotel, being copied and other projects from Amsterdam to Beirut.

headline: Umenyiora's Affidavit Targets Giants GM
summary: A person familiar with the situation indicates that the defensive end signed an affidavit claiming Jerry Reese reneged on a promise to renegotiate Umenyiora's contract.

headline: World Bank Can Help, Says IMF Candidate
summary: Mexican central banker Agustín Carstens, campaigning in Beijing for the top IMF job, said the World Bank should be involved in a rescue package for Greece as a way to ease the cost of the bailout.

headline: Carlin Romano: The Dalai Lama, Marxist?
summary: The brave spiritual leader's unusual blind spot.

headline: Homes with Pools to Lounge By -- Photos
summary: Tour homes in La Eliana, Spain; Kilauea, Hawaii; and Los Angeles.

headline: Airbus Orders Pressure  Boeing
summary: Big orders announced by two Asian airlines for a more fuel-efficient version of Airbus's A320 jetliner will pressure rival Boeing to offer a version of its own 737 jet with more-efficient engines or leapfrog Airbus with an altogether new aircraft design that boasts lower operating costs.

headline: Vancouver Tallies Damage After Hockey-Fan Rioting
summary: Officials were left reeling after a spasm of violence and rioting following a loss by the local hockey in the Stanley Cup final game left more than 100 injured, at least one critically, and a smoldering, looted city center.

headline: N.Y. Jobless Rate Steady in May
summary: New York City's employers kept adding jobs in May as the city's unemployment rate remained steady at 8.6%.

headline: Facebook Seeks to Shape Mobile-App Software
summary: Facebook is angling to play a bigger role in shaping the way software gets developed for mobile devices, encouraging developers who write Facebook apps to do so for mobile gadgets using a relatively new standard called HTML5.

headline: Maintaining Resolve in Libya
summary: Time is working against Gadhafi and for the people he has oppressed, writes U.K. Foreign Secretary William Hague.

headline: Macy's, Union Agree to Contract
summary: Macy's and union officials representing 4,000 workers in Greater New York reached a deal on a new contract, averting a strike.

headline: Breakup Becomes Social-Media Event
summary: When billionaire Wang Gongquan, one of China's most famous investors, decided to leave his wife for his mistress, he broke the news to family and friends -- and hundreds of thousands of strangers -- in a message online.

headline: Euro Suffers on Greek Woes
summary: Fears of a Greek default swelled, sending the euro to a record low against the Swiss franc. A late buying spree of risk-related assets pulled the single currency off a three-week low below $1.41.

headline: What's on Around Europe
summary: The Weekend Journal's guide to exhibitions, concerts and events across Europe.

headline: Sarkozy Urges Compromise on Greek Debt
summary: French President Nicolas Sarkozy urged European leaders to find a compromise on Greece's debt crisis in order to stabilize the euro.
